title: 107_s156
content: The "After School Education and Anti-Crime Act of 2001" aims to improve academic and social outcomes for students, reduce juvenile crime, and provide productive activities during after school hours to prevent youth from becoming victims of crime. Congress finds that today's youth face increased social risks, spend more time unsupervised, and are most at risk of violence between 3 p.m. and 6 p.m. Academic failure consequences are more severe in 2001. Many states have shown the benefits of after school programs. The consequences of academic failure are more severe in 2001. After school programs have been proven to help address social issues like drugs, alcohol, and gang involvement. Many governors support increasing after school programs through a Federal/State partnership. Leading police chiefs and prosecutors also endorse these programs. The Fraternal Order of Police and the International Union of Police Associations, representing 360,000 police officers, are urging public officials to provide after school programs for school-age children and teens in the United States. They emphasize the importance of safe and positive learning environments during after school hours. The goals of the Act include increasing academic success, promoting safe after school environments, providing alternatives to negative activities, and reducing juvenile crime. The Act also amends the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act to increase program authorization. Section 10904 of the Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to include various stakeholders in the program and require recipients to provide a minimum of 35 percent of the project's annual cost from sources other than government funds. The recipient must provide a minimum of 35 percent of the project's annual cost from non-government sources, which can be in cash or in kind. Additionally, they can use up to 25 percent of the annual cost from funds provided by the Secretary under other Federal programs. The recipient must ensure that they maintain their fiscal effort from non-Federal sources each year for the activities funded under the project. SEC. 7. USES OF FUNDS. Section 10905 of the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to allow grants for establishing or expanding community learning centers that provide various activities, including job skills preparation. Additionally, after school programs must include at least 2 specified activities. After school programs must include mentoring, academic assistance, recreational activities, and technology training. They may also include drug, alcohol, and gang prevention activities, health and nutrition counseling, and job skills preparation activities. After school programs must include mentoring, academic assistance, recreational activities, technology training, health and nutrition counseling, and job skills preparation activities. At least 2/3 of the funds appropriated for each fiscal year should be used for after school programs. These programs can also offer expanded opportunities for children and youth. SEC. 8. ADMINISTRATION. Section 10905 of the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to include provisions for local educational agencies, schools, or consortia to involve volunteers from various communities, ensure youth participation in designing after-school activities, and use creative outreach methods. The 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act now includes provisions for involving volunteers, ensuring youth participation in designing after-school activities, conducting creative outreach methods, requesting donations of equipment, and collaborating with State and local park agencies to avoid duplication of activities. SEC. 9. Community Learning Center defined as including law enforcement organizations like the Police Athletic and Activity League. SEC. 10. Authorization of appropriations increased to $1,000,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 and gradually increasing to $1,500,000,000 for fiscal year 2006. SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act and its amendments will be effective on October 1, 2001.
